;CNN 在经历了动荡的一年领导陷入困境的新闻网络后罢免了首席执行官 Chris Licht在一份该死的杂志简介中，并且越来越多的人意识到他已经失去了该网络记者的信任。

;

;这一变化是在周三早上的 CNN 编辑会议上宣布的，就在 Licht 表示他将“战斗”的两天后”以赢得周围人的信任。

;

;CNN 母公司华纳兄弟探索频道的首席执行官大卫扎斯拉夫任命了一个四人临时领导团队，并在编辑会议上表示，他将彻底寻找 Licht 的替代者。

;

;Licht 的任务是努力让 CNN 更受该国政治分歧双方的欢迎；在美国前总统唐纳德·特朗普的多次攻击之后，共和党人对该网络越来越怀疑。

;

;但该网络中的一些人认为 Licht 的变革授权是对他们过去工作的否定，以及对 Licht 的现场市政厅采访特朗普上个月招致了广泛批评。

;

;今年早些时候，莱希特改组了该网络的早间节目，但事实证明那是不成功的，并导致长期担任主角的唐·莱蒙被解雇。建立新的黄金时段阵容的努力进展缓慢，自从克里斯·库莫 (Chris Cuomo) 于 2021 年 12 月被解雇后，凯特兰·柯林斯 (Kaitlan Collins) 最近才被任命为晚上 9 点的空缺，没有固定主持人。

;

;Licht 负责监督裁员去年，Zaslav 决定在 CNN+ 流媒体服务启动仅数周后就将其关闭。

;

;曾制作过 MSNBC 的早安乔、CBS 的早间新闻节目和斯蒂芬科尔伯特的深夜节目的 Licht 被任命为Zaslav 仅在一年多前接替了内部颇受欢迎的前任 Jeff Zucker。祖克因未透露与 CNN 高管的双方同意的关系而被解雇。

;

;CNN 首席执行官杰夫扎克在与同事发生关系后辞职

;

;扎斯拉夫在给 CNN 员工的备忘录中说，这份工作“这绝非易事，尤其是在发生巨大破坏和变革的时期。”

;

;“克里斯倾注了全部心血，”他说。 “他对新闻业和这项业务有着深厚的热爱，这一点在他的整个任期内都很明显。不幸的是，事情并没有像我们希望的那样发展——最终这取决于我。”

;

;Licht 没有立即回复征求意见的消息。

;

;Licht 在周五出版的《大西洋》杂志题为“深入了解 CNN 的崩溃”，事实证明这让他很尴尬，而且很可能决定了他的命运。一些记者因为 Licht 在他到达之前批评 CNN 的一些 Covid-19 报道而感到愤怒。

;

;CNN 的一些主要主持人——Jake Tapper、Anderson Cooper 和 Erin Burnett——私下表达了他们对 Licht 的保留意见据《华尔街日报》周二晚间发表的一篇文章称，领导层。

;

;与此同时，观众正在消失。 CNN 的黄金时段收视率在 5 月份为 494,000，比 4 月份下降了 16%，还不到其最接近的新闻竞争对手 MSNBC 的一半。

;

;Zaslav 任命了 CNN 的四位现任高管——Amy Entelis、Virginia Moseley、Eric Sherling 和 David Leavy – 在寻找替代者的同时运行网络。

;

;“我们得到了很好的帮助，让我们能够花时间进行深思熟虑和彻底的新搜索领导者，”Zaslav 在备忘录中说。

;美国和中国在一年一度的香格里拉大酒店展开激烈的口水战本月在国际战略研究所的主持下在新加坡举行的对话。与近年来一样，两国国防部长相互指责对方危害地区和平与稳定。

;

;今年，双方再次交锋，发表严厉声明。鉴于活动前夕的挑衅性军事演习使美国和中国的海军舰艇和军用飞机在南海及其上空危险地接近碰撞，似乎警告灯正在闪烁。

;

;然而，就在新加坡的审议落下帷幕之际，美国和中国周一在北京进行了高层双边会谈。一天后，双方发表了简短的声明，其中关键词和短语的选择是相似的。在外交语言中，两个对手是对话者，这种语义重叠被认为是相当积极的。对于在新加坡可见的敌意，这是值得欢迎的。

;

;美国负责东亚和太平洋事务的助理国务卿丹尼尔克里滕布林克和外交部副部长马朝旭在北京举行了会谈。会谈结束后，美国发表声明说，“双方进行了坦诚而富有成效的讨论，这是为保持开放的沟通渠道和巩固两国近期高层外交所做的持续努力的一部分”。

;

;发表的声明中国外交部回应了这一观点并指出：“双方就推动中美关系改善、妥善管控分歧进行了坦诚、建设性和富有成果的沟通”。 “卓有成效”二字值得关注。

;

;两国国防部长在香格里拉对话会上的发言，让我们看到了美中两国在核心问题上如何努力表达和维护各自立场正在受到争议——即台湾和南中国海的航行自由。

;

;美国国防部长劳埃德·奥斯汀和他的中国国防部长李尚福没有表示美中关系普遍脆弱。在新加坡直接交谈，除非在尴尬的握手过程中进行非正式交谈。早些时候，中国拒绝了美国提出的在两国将军峰会期间举行会晤的提议。

;

;奥斯汀在讲话中传达的信息与他在去年香格里拉对话会上的讲话一致。在强调美国在联合国海洋法会议上阐明的对国际法和航行自由的承诺的同时，他重申华盛顿坚持其台湾政策是“维持海峡现状，符合我们长期以来的立场”。坚持一个中国政策，并履行我们在《台湾关系法》下的既定义务。”

;

;在南中国海的争议声索中，奥斯汀表示美国将“继续与我们的盟友和伙伴合作维护航行和飞越自由。让我再次强调仲裁庭 2016 年裁决的重要性。这是具有法律约束力的，也是最终的。”

;

;这是他就任国防部长以来首次在外部论坛上露面，他在习近平主席提出的全球安全倡议的背景下阐述了自己的言论，并表示推动“共同、综合、合作、可持续的安全，探索对话而非对抗、伙伴而非结盟、共赢而非零和”的新安全之路。

;

;李继而重申了中国的承诺到台湾统一。他说：“我们将以最大的诚意和最大的努力争取和平统一的前景，但不承诺放弃使用武力。如果有人胆敢把台湾从中国分裂出去，中国军方会毫不犹豫。我们将不惧任何对手，不惜一切代价坚决捍卫国家主权和领土完整。”

;

;这个棘手的问题是否会导致北京诉诸武力仍不确定，但显然不会保持沉默桌面上的那个选项。然而，乌克兰持续不断的战争应该提醒我们，曾经被认为难以想象的事情可能会迅速升级。

;

;关于涉及东南亚国家的地区领土争端，李说：“我们致力于促进合作，在相互尊重的基础上，我们地区的集体和共同安全。”北京首选的模板仍然是南海行为准则，但与受影响国家的共识仍然难以实现。

;

;事实上，区域对话者的观点仍然大相径庭。在李克强讲话后的问答环节，菲律宾海岸警卫队副局长杰伊·特里斯坦·塔里埃拉准将提出了一个中肯的问题。

;

;“你提到中国希望促进对话而不是对抗，”他说。说。 “所以我的问题是关于中国与菲律宾以及可能与该地区其他国家的海上互动的言行之间明显脱节。

;

;“你们的海岸警卫队将军用级激光发射到菲律宾海岸菲律宾专属经济区内的警卫船。所以中国说的是对话，中国的行动却是对抗。因此，我的问题是，为什么中国的言行会有很大的不同？”

;

;这个问题仍然没有答案。显然，北京必须言出必行，以表明其坚持其既定价值观和优先对话而非对抗的诚意。

;

;北京已承诺支持贸易以支持整体经济复苏，但中国的出口由于全球需求疲软，一直在苦苦挣扎。

;

;

;

;中国的出口自年初以来首次出现下滑，5 月份同比下降 7.5% 至 283.5 美元亿美元，与 4 月份 8.5% 的增幅形成鲜明对比。

;

;在 1 月份和 2 月份的总出货量下降 6.8% 之后，中国 3 月份的出口也增长了 14.8%，相比之下

;

;中国官方制造业采购经理人指数 5 月份进一步收缩，海外需求疲软已被归咎于此。

;

;5 月份的出口额也是第二位- 自 2022 年 5 月以来的最低水平，仅高于 2 月份受季节性影响的 2138 亿美元。

;

;包含高科技产品的类别造成了大部分痛苦，因为在家工作设备的购买量减少以及全球技术裁员影响了需求，”Moody's Analytics 的经济学家 Sarah Tan 说。

;< p>;“从好的方面来看，汽车出口增长了一倍多，其中电动汽车增长最为强劲。但这还不足以弥补其他出口类别的疲软。”

;

;5 月份中国对美国的出货量同比下降 18.24%，而同期为 6.5% 4 月，连续第 10 个月下降。

;

;与此同时，对欧盟的出口在经历了两个月的短暂上升后，恢复负增长，与去年同期相比下降 7.03%。< /p>;

;对东南亚国家联盟（东盟）国家的出货量在 5 月份下降了 15.92%，而东南亚国家联盟（东盟）国家是 3 月和 4 月中国强劲整体出口的主要推动力。

;

;;

;中国 5 月份进口额同比下降 4.5% 至 2177 亿美元，高于 4 月份的 7.9% 的降幅。

;

;“这主要是由于大宗商品进口下降账单。事实上，5 月份全球能源价格同比下降 33.9%，而全球食品价格同比下降 16.3%。牛津经济研究院高级经济学家 Lloyd Chan 表示，进口下降也可能反映了与中国贸易摩擦的增加。

;

;不过，中国在 5 月份进口了创纪录的 1202 万吨大豆，增长了 24

;

;

;

;中国 5 月份贸易顺差 658 亿美元，较 4 月份的 902 亿美元大幅下降。

;

;“中国贸易顺差5 月份顺差收窄，出口降幅大于进口。出口回落是在 3 月和 4 月连续强劲增长之后出现的。进口延续了 10 月份开始的回落，”穆迪分析公司的 Tan 补充道。

;

;5 月份中国对美国的贸易顺差达到 281.6 亿美元，低于 4 月份的 296.8 亿美元。

;< h3>;;

;总理李强上周表示，尽管今年开局良好，但中国经济复苏尚未稳固，投资银行对增长失去动力表示担忧，他们预计中国经济将提供更多支持

;

;“出口疲软证实，随着全球经济放缓，中国需要依赖内需，”中点资产管理公司总裁兼首席经济学家张志伟表示。

;

;“下半年全球需求可能进一步疲软，政府在今年余下时间增加国内消费的压力更大。”

;

;统一的国内市场是否有助于解决中国经济增长问题？

;

;周一，中国增加了建立统一国内市场的努力的细节——重点是通过高效的生产、分销和流通建设强大的国内经济，同时遏制市场分割问题。

;

;北京将修订反不正当竞争法，出台公平竞争审查制度，扩大外商投资市场准入。

;

;积极建设国内统一市场恢复投资者信心和释放长期增长动力的努力。

;

;“展望未来，我们认为出口将进一步下降，然后在今年晚些时候触底反弹。 Capital Economics 的分析师表示，尽管中国以外的利率接近峰值，但大幅加息的滞后影响将在今年晚些时候削弱发达经济体的活动，在大多数情况下引发温和衰退。

; p>;“至于进口，我们认为它们将在未来几个季度继续复苏，因为重新开放带来的推动力将继续发挥作用。”

;香港医院管理局应将专业工程师的人数增加一倍，以监督医疗设备工程一个专家小组建议，由承包商自行维护和维修设施。

;

;当局周三还誓言要采取法律行动，追究承包商因涉嫌未能达到维修和维护标准而承担的责任，在今年早些时候发生了一系列涉及坠落物体的事件之后。由专家组处理的一项审查是由 2 月份在一家公立医院落下的手术灯引发的。

;

;“我们过去常常依靠承包商对高风险医疗设备进行维护工作 [没有生物医学工程师的监督]，但这些事件让我们意识到加强监督的重要性，”管理局行政总裁高百星博士说。

;

;香港医院应该使用技术来检查设施, 增加检查”

;

;柯还表示，目前每三年检查一次建筑物的做法并不理想。 “内部工作人员应该接管工作，并根据建筑物的年龄和状况进行更频繁的检查，”他说。

;

;邮报已经联系了负责维护建筑物的公司 Getinge早期事件中心的手术灯，以征求意见。

;

;由测量、工程和企业传播等领域的专家组成的工作组在经过三个月的审查后提供了一份包含 23 条建议的清单

;

;香港医院管理局承认老化设施维修困难

;

;

;

;

;目前有 15 名生物医学工程师为当局工作。

;

;万说，43 家公立医院每年进行约 351,000 例维修。

;

;“生物医学工程师全神贯注于设备采购，而无暇监督[承包商]的维修和维护工作，这并不理想。”

;

;

;Wan 将一连串事件与建筑物和设施老化以及大流行期间定期维护中断联系起来, 并补充说，医院亦应妥善记录设备的使用手册，以协助监督工作。

;

;另一方面，委员会建议与设备工作分开的一般楼宇维修工作，应由内部处理，不依赖

;

;Wan 表示，当局医院共有约 740 名设施管理人员，他们应该参与大楼维修工程，理由是他们“拥有更强的主人翁意识”。< /p>;

;

;“他们应密切留意容易漏水的地方，这会增加风险的混凝土剥落。他们还应该经常检查高风险地方，把医院当作自己的家。”

;

;当局管理的300座建筑物中，有一半以上是30多年前竣工的。一些建筑物的历史超过 85 年。

;

;Wan 补充说，与外部承包商相比，内部设施工作人员会发现更容易适应维护计划。

;

;但 Ko 说考虑到每个病例的独特性，将不会成为检查易受攻击设施的频率的硬性指标。

;

;他说，每家医院都将设立一个安全委员会，以监督维修和保养

;

;香港医院护士因配药器故障而触电受伤

;

;注意到在短期内增加生物医学工程师的数量存在困难Ko 表示，技术将在未来一段时间内用于提高检测结构缺陷的效率。

;

;该机构的战略和规划总监程伟权博士表示，红外线扫描仪和湿度计是正在开发的工具之一用于辅助常规检查方法。

;当局正与理工大学合作，测试先进传感器和雷达在容易漏水的区域（包括厨房和洗手间）的应用，以促进及早发现混凝土剥落

;中国应通过区域贸易协定和离岸贸易进一步吸引人们对使用人民币日益增长的兴趣根据中国银行的一份报告，随着北京方面以“有序”的方式增加人民币在全球的使用。

;

;Beijing believes the US is using international law as a “cover” for provocations and feels it has “no choice” but to intercept US warships in the Taiwan Strait, according to mainland Chinese observers.

;

;But US-based maritime law specialists said China's actions risked “the possibility of conflict” and were an indication Beijing was disregarding international practice.

;

;On June 3, a People's Liberation Army (PLA) warship came within 137 metres (150 yards) of an American destroyer during a joint Canada-US operation through the Taiwan Strait, the Pentagon said.

;

;US officials accused the PLA of making an “unsafe and unprofessional” manoeuvre, and warned that China was violating the international maritime law on safe passage and raising the risk of a military miscalculation.

;

;China's foreign ministry called the manoeuvre “lawful” and “justified” in the face of US provocation, accusing Washington of “stirring up trouble” in the Taiwan Strait.

;

;The incident coincided with the release of an analysis from the South China Sea Strategic Situation Probing Initiative , a Beijing-based defence think tank, which argued that China has the right under international law to intercept US warships sailing through the strait.

;

;Chinese paper accuses Canadian press of hyping PLA ship's 'very scary' move

;

;US forces have long cited the laws on “innocent passage” to defend their voyages through sensitive areas such as the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea.

;

;But the think tank argued that coastal states such as China have the right to determine what constitutes “innocent passage” under Article 25 of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS).

;

;“There has never been an unrestricted right of navigation in the convention or in general international law,” its analysis read. “US warships may exercise the right of innocent passage, but at the same time must respect the coastal state's determination of whether the passage is innocent.”

;

;But diplomatic analysts from both the US and China questioned this reading.

;

;“Under international law, innocent passage is only relevant within a state's 12-nautical-mile [22km] territorial sea,” said Gregory Poling, director of the Asia Maritime Transparency Initiative at the Centre for Strategic and International Studies.

;

;He said the strait, which is 130km (70 nautical miles) wide at its narrowest point, is “far too wide to be considered territorial waters under any circumstances”.

;

;Ma Jianying, director of the Centre for Maritime Security Studies at Shandong Normal University, said: “Objectively speaking, the US warships have the right to pass through the Taiwan Strait.”

;

;But according to Ma, China views US navigation exercises as a “tactic to bully China”, and sending out its own warships was a signal to deter future passage.

;

;“China has no other choice,” Ma said. “It can't stop the US warships passing across the Taiwan Strait, so it has to send out its own warships.”

;

;Most Europeans would want to stay neutral in a US-China war over Taiwan: study

;

;China has long considered US warship passages through the strait as needlessly provocative and a challenge to its claims of sovereignty over Taiwan – which Beijing considers to be a renegade province that should be brought back to the fold, by force if necessary.

;

;Immediately following the most recent incident, Senior Colonel Shi Yi, a spokesperson for PLA Eastern Theatre Command, said US actions were undermining regional peace and stability and sent “the wrong signals to Taiwan independence forces”.

;

;James Kraska, chairman of the Stockton Centre for International Law at the US Naval War College, said: “[Beijing] routinely exercises its right of navigation and overflight near neighbours and distant states, but creates 'incidents' when the United States conducts the same operations at the same distance from China.”

;

;“China's actions increase the likelihood of further situations like we saw over the weekend and raise the possibility of conflict,” he said.

;

;But Ni Lexiong, a professor at the Shanghai University of Political Science and Law, said that the latest incident was not a matter of who was right under international law, but rather a matter of deterrence and counter-deterrence.

;

;“China's logic is that when countering US actions, why should it abide by international law that has become cover for Washington to intimidate and provoke Beijing?” he said.

;

;However, Poling warned that such a posture only calls into question Beijing's commitment to regional and global security.

;

;“China does not want to be bound by international laws that it finds constraining or at odds with its policy preferences,” he said.

;

;“That desire for extreme exceptionalism does raise tensions between China on one hand and a growing coalition of anxious states on the other, which includes all of the G7, Europe, and most of China's neighbours in East and Southeast Asia.”

; Wed, 07 Jun 2023 21:50:01 +0800 Democrats’ disastrous US debt ceiling deal snatches defeat from jaws of victoryhttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3223234/democrats-disastrous-us-debt-ceiling-deal-snatches-defeat-jaws-victory?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.07 21:30;
;;

;There is an odious American political mythology concerning bipartisanship, according to which bitter adversaries, scarred by battle, find common ground, join hands and stroll off together into the sunset. It is mostly hokum.

;

;Ulysses S. Grant did not reconcile with Robert E. Lee after Appomattox. Franklin D. Roosevelt did not reconcile with Herbert Hoover during the Great Depression, nor John F. Kennedy with Richard Nixon after the 1960 election. One does hear sugary reminiscences of Ronald Reagan and Tip O'Neill swapping blarney. But the real O'Neill fought Reagan – on principle and on politics – with everything he had.

;

;In the spirit of the myth, US President Joe Biden recently praised House Speaker Kevin McCarthy after committing an appalling act of political surrender – on tax enforcement, social programmes, student debt, the environment and more.

;

;Worst of all, Biden abandoned the principle that the debt ceiling should not obstruct progressive priorities in the future. But everything is all right, we are told, because Biden and McCarthy worked things out together.

;

;But the White House and Treasury had at least three plausibly legal, wholly constitutional ways to defuse the supposed crisis without involving McCarthy and his increasingly unhinged Republican caucus. The administration could have minted a high-value platinum coin and deposited it at the US Federal Reserve, resorted to consol bonds which never mature, or issued premium bonds.

;

;Instead, they emerged from their trenches, waved a white flag and bargained away the keys to their fortress – all so the besieging army would go away for few years. Worse, the Democrats knew the Republican troops were divided and mutinous. Biden showed that when he told them, correctly, to get lost when they first approached.

;

;But there is an even bigger truth that no one wants to admit: the Republicans' big bomb was always a dud. The Treasury, by law, cannot stop or prioritise payments. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and her predecessors have long emphasised this.

;

;Even if you cross the “limit”, the cheques must still go out. The debt ceiling only prevents the Treasury from issuing new bonds. In the worst case, the Fed's Treasury General Account would have insufficient funds to cover the cheques.

;

;At that point, the Fed probably could have issued a line of credit – an overdraft – to ensure the payments were honoured. Unsecured, no-interest, overnight overdrafts are not covered by the debt ceiling and are arguably a legal possibility. The Fed's own records state the matter would be decided by its board of governors.

;

;The question might ultimately be tested in court, but so what? If the Fed so decided, or if a court so ordered, some of those Treasury cheques could bounce, becoming unsecured claims on the Treasury. If banks refused to honour them, how long would it take before the Fed begged Congress to resolve the “crisis”? I suspect that would happen well before markets opened the next day.

;

;If breaching the debt limit had really risked “catastrophe”, the blame would have laid with those Republicans who decided to make an issue of it, and they almost certainly would have folded. If, against all logic, they chose political suicide, so much the better for the Democrats.

;

;The White House held the big guns either way, yet still it surrendered. It seems that Biden's advisers did not particularly care about the concessions made, and that at least some people had a strong economic reason to avoid the aftermath of a default.

;

;Let's examine that scenario. Suppose McCarthy's forces held, Biden did not surrender, the Fed issued overdrafts and the political stalemate dragged on. Even then, life would go on normally, except that maturing Treasury bonds would be paid off in cash because they would no longer be rolled over.

;

;Bondholders might not like that, and they might use their cash to buy something else. As Hillary Clinton warned in The New York Times, the international dollar would fall, implying the tiny elite who live by the international dollar would take the bigger hit. For the rest of the country, it would be analogous to when Roosevelt suspended the gold standard and launched the New Deal in 1933.

;

;US industry would become more competitive, and industrial and manufacturing jobs would start to return. Though there are costs to a lower US dollar, these must be weighed against the benefits. Besides, a weaker dollar is coming anyway.

;

;The “catastrophe” scenario was absurd from the start. This was really about the character of the Democratic Party. Would it continue to cater to Big Finance or would it be forced to represent the interests its own voters and the American people?

;

;Mainstream Republicans backing US debt ceiling deal welcome sign of sanity

;

;If Biden is re-elected, congressional Democrats will face the same choice again in 2025. They can agree to more concessions and again hide behind the rhetoric of “bipartisan cooperation”, or they can finally refuse to submit to extortion.

;

;And if Biden is defeated? The Republicans will do whatever they want with federal programmes, regulations, taxes and the debt ceiling. This latest disgraceful episode has made such an outcome more likely. After all, who needs a Democratic Party that won't stand up for itself or its constituents?

;China is planning to regulate file-sharing among nearby mobile devices for “national security” reasons, in a move expected to impact the use of such communication apps, such as Apple's AirDrop.

;

;According to a draft released by China's top internet watchdog, the new rules aim to limit the use of any “file transfer services that rely on Wi-fi, Bluetooth, and other information technologies to form networks instantly and communicate to other devices over a short-range”.

;

;The Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) posted the draft regulation on its website on Tuesday as it launched a month-long public consultation on the matter.

;

;The CAC move is the latest in Beijing's drive to “safeguard national security”. File-sharing service AirDrop – which is available on iPhones and other Apple devices – was used during public demonstrations last winter against the mainland's strict zero-Covid restrictions, and also during anti-government protests in Hong Kong in 2019.

;

;Similar close-range wireless communication features launched in recent years by other companies include Files by Google and Fast Share on Google's Android operating service.

;

;Chinese phone makers Vivo, Xiaomi and Oppo also offer such file transfer services that are compatible among their own devices.

;

;The regulation says technology companies must undergo security assessment if they wish to include any features that could be used “for public expression and social mobilisation”. All users of such features must also sign up under their real names.

;

;According to Gao Fuping, a law professor at the East China University of Political Science and Law in Shanghai, the real-name registration requirement aims to “fill a loophole” in content control when it comes to network transmission services like AirDrop, even though China rolled out the real-name system for online activities a decade ago.

;

;“It is mainly about cybersecurity, and the core aim is to ensure all the information transmission can be traced in case problematic things happen,” Gao said.

;

;Launched in 2011, Apple's AirDrop feature has been a convenient tool to share files with nearby users over Wi-fi or Bluetooth, without the need to rely on an internet connection. Images can be shared anonymously and AirDrop only shows nearby phones under their chosen nicknames, with no way for the user to identify the sender.

;

;The draft regulation also stipulates that such “close-range mesh network” service providers “save relevant records” and report to internet regulators if they find any “illegal information” or “dissemination of harmful information”.

;

;However, it does not elaborate what kind of information might be considered illegal or harmful.

;

;Apple's iPhone commands a fifth of the mobile device market share in mainland China and around half of Hong Kong's, according to the latest data from tech market trackers CounterPoint Research.

;

;Last November, protests broke out in multiple Chinese cities over frustrations relating to the government's draconian zero-Covid policy of lockdowns, border closures, mass testing and strict quarantine. AirDrop was used then to share anti-government images, Western media reports said.

;

;Earlier that month, in an update to its operating system, Apple imposed a 10-minute time limit on exchanging AirDrop content via all iPhones sold in mainland China. This was seen as a move to prevent Chinese iPhone users from evading the country's strict web censorship.

;

;Although Apple did not explain why it made such a change, it came shortly after a protester – later nicknamed “bridge man” – unfurled two banners on a bridge in Beijing, calling for an end to the harsh Covid-19 policy and criticising the ruling Communist Party.

;

;While references to the protest were blocked by internet censors, photos were reportedly shared among the Chinese public via AirDrop.

;

;Also, during anti-government protests in Hong Kong in 2019, young activists used AirDrop to send out messages on the subway and in other public places, inviting the public to join the demonstrations.

;

;Angela Zhang, an associate professor of law at the University of Hong Kong, said the latest tightening measures from Beijing “collectively aim to strengthen the CAC's control over [internet] content and information dissemination”.

;

;But she also noted that the new rules were unlikely to have a significant impact on the tech industry as a whole, as they primarily appeared to target the AirDrop function.

;

;Apple's mainland China headquarters did not immediately reply to a request for comment.

;

;The draft CAC rules also require technology companies to set “receiving off” as default for such features.

;

;Snapshot previews must also be disabled, unless users give consent. Current AirDrop settings allow users to be sent information deemed sensitive or explicit, though they can choose to accept or decline.

;

;In recent years, there have been calls for Big Tech companies like Apple to modify features like AirDrop to avoid their potential misuse, where offenders can easily harass users by sharing explicit images, which can be especially triggering for sexual assault survivors.
